title: Housing officials: Fort Knox residents now have recycling options - United States Army
summary: Fort Knox, a military community, is partnering with Meade County to provide recycling services for residents. The partnership aims to increase recycling capacity and meet climate strategy initiatives. The program includes drop-off bins for plastics, paper, aluminum, and steel, and plans are in place to expand recycling to include glass in the future.

title: Quadpack: A range of five mono-material recyclable lipsticks - Premium beauty
summary: Quadpack has launched a range of five monomaterial lipsticks made from recyclable materials like aluminum, polypropylene (PP), and polyethylene (PET). The lipsticks are designed to be refillable and offer various shapes and features, catering to different formulas and brand identities. The company emphasizes the sustainability of these products, providing life-cycle assessments to demonstrate their reduced environmental impact.

title: Approval sought for new landfill near Glendale - Niagara Now
summary: Walker Industries, a waste management company in Niagara, is planning a new landfill phase, proposing to develop an abandoned quarry. The company emphasizes its commitment to environmental protection, citing a state-of-the-art liner system and a rigorous environmental assessment process. Walker also highlights its existing efforts in recycling, composting, and generating renewable energy from landfill gas.

title: In Vietnam, young people embrace green lifestyles - TUOI TRE NEWS
summary: Vietnamese youth are leading the charge in sustainable living by developing innovative solutions using recycled and natural materials. Businesses like The Greenmart Vietnam and Tiem Thua Nuoc are creating daily essentials and products from materials like bamboo and recycled plastics.  This trend is also evident in universities, where students are crafting furniture and other items from plastic waste, emphasizing a circular economy and promoting sustainable production practices.
product_or_process: Products made from recycled plastic, bamboo, grass, sedge, water hyacinth, and bulrush

title: Dubai's recycling programme treats over 8,000kg of waste every week - Khaleej Times
summary: Dubai Municipality has launched the Smart Sustainability Oasis (SSO) project, a network of 17 recycling centers that collect 18 different types of recyclable materials. The SSO project, which started in 2018, has diverted close to 2.5 million tonnes of waste from landfills, promoting waste segregation at source and supporting the recycling industry in Dubai.  The project aims to expand, with a new center planned for the coming year, and utilizes recycled shipping containers, solar energy, and accessibility features.
